@vinothchandar Still WIP, `HoodieCompactedLogRecordScanner` and `HoodieLogBlock` have many fundamental changes (some of which I'm not in favor of but not sure how to avoid), would appreciate some feedback to iterate over the design, cleaning up the code in progress.

Its not all written records, its wrapper information about all written records. Actual payload is deflated already. We can't make this optional , since the Index api needs this information to update the index back (this could be no-op for BloomIndex, but will not be for something like HBaseIndex/CassandraIndex). So don't like to special case it at that level.

Happy to consider other alternatives.
@vinothchandar Changes incorporated according to our discussion, running an end-to-end test again, please give feedback in the meantime.
Thanks Vinoth. Makes sense with what you are saying. Let me see if I can get numbers around how much time (apart from space) we can save (if any) with it. I will update once I have those numbers.

The best approach here could be to add a method to the HoodieIndex ..

 `isIndexImplicit()` => which returns true of false, depending on whether the index is implicitly updated with storage.. This would return `true` for BloomIndex and `false` for Cassandra/HBaseIndex

we can then use this inside StorageHandles to determine whether to add the successful records into writestatus.. 

PS: I still need to triple check whether the index update is the only reason why we propagate this.

Based on an initial investigation using the worst possible workload (a single column projection has excellent parquet/columnar performance, while row based data is fully read & deserialized)

```
select count(`_hoodie_record_key`)  from table where datestr>{date_range} 
```

Here's what we found : 

- As long as the scans are small (<100GB) we expect to see < 10% variance in the query run time and even if the scans are not massive (scanning more than 500GB of data), we expect to see < 20%. 
- For scanning more than 500GB of data, the choice between RTView and ROView becomes significant based on use-case. Things like a ML training pipeline that scours a lot of data, can simply go to ROView 
- When fast data reaches more than 50GB, we see almost double the query latency. Note: This cost also depends on amount of cold data scanned. Remember this is the worst performance as the test query is doing a single flat column projection - which performs the best on cold data and does not help scans on the fast data much.
- Memory and CPU usage is increased for small scans as updates are loaded into memory and conditional checks are added to merge fast data with cold data. But this evens out for big scans. 



|Parquet Data (GB) | Log Data (GB) | Query Latency Increase % | Memory(% increase) | Cumulative CPU(% increase)|
| -- | -- | -- |-- |-- |
|0.505 | 0.232 | 5.555555556 | 40.81746766 | 61.37638199
|15 | 3 | 7.575757576 | 49.52813364 | 68.70778338
|57 | 8 | 2 | 46.978982 | 70.02830956
|142 | 23 | 20.68965517 | 12.33708618 | 64.71884707
|561 | 65 | 129.7959184 | 3.410041347 | 42.06951578
|906 | 72 | 106.9090909 | 19.08305902 | 17.53314515
|998 | 75 | 28.85117493 | 15.31893635 | 8.356814546


But, again, this gives you real-time & read-optimized views all at the same time! 1 system! So its still worth it. :)
thanks @prazanna for the awesome benchmark and analysis ..

Early thoughts.  

#### Implement a Spark File Format 
 - `HoodieRealtimeFileFormat` modelled after ParquetFileFormat inside Spark
 - Can wrap `org.apache.spark.sql.execution.datasources.parquet.ParquetFileFormat` & another piece which merges output from log as Iterator[Row] 
 - Use `HadoopFsRelation` to pass in the file format if needed, with schema & everything

#### Reading output from the IPF RecordReader 

 -  `org.apache.spark.sql.execution.datasources.parquet.ParquetReadSupport` inside Spark helps convert Parquet records to Row. 
 -  However, current IPFs HoodieInputFormat & HoodieRealtimeInputFormat both extend from MapredParquetInputFormat, which seems to hardcode `ArrayWritable` as the written value.    hence the core merge/compaction logic needs to have templatized types to support this. 

```
public class MapredParquetInputFormat extends FileInputFormat<Void, ArrayWritable> {
    private static final Log LOG = LogFactory.getLog(MapredParquetInputFormat.class);
    private final ParquetInputFormat<ArrayWritable> realInput;
```
- We won't be calling the RecordReader level apis directly at all. 

#### Filtering & listing such that only right splits are considered. 

 - TBD. Guess, is forcing `convertMetastoreParquet=false` would get Spark to call ipf.getSplits() which does the job and later only valid splits are passed into the closure returned from FileFormat
 - Per code in `DataSource.scala` pruning paths in the `path` option before creating the relation would work too 

```
case (format: FileFormat, _) =>
        val allPaths = caseInsensitiveOptions.get("path") ++ paths
        val hadoopConf = sparkSession.sessionState.newHadoopConf()
```

Incorporated changes. 

**IMPORTANT** : At the moment we store the payloadclass name in hoodie.properties. This file is written only once (when the dataset is created) and not updated during the life-cycle of the dataset. This means clients cannot change their PayloadClass during the lifecycle of the dataset. Given that this payloadclass will ultimately also lie in the Hive servers (for realtimeinputstream), should we keep the hoodie.properties immutable ? 

I also noticed that we have a mix of 2 spaces and 4 spaces in many classes. According to the developer docs, I think you guys chose to have 2 spaces : https://google.github.io/styleguide/javaguide.html#s4.2-block-indentation. The problem I noticed is that my Intellij defaults to a profile with 4 spaces. I noticed that the classes under hoodie-spark also have 4 spaces which might mean your IDE defaults to something similar. I'll fix my IDE to make sure I follow 2 spaces.

thanks for pointing out. yes, i have been meaning to format the whole project once and set/enforce uniformity..  In any case, I generally use the rule of thumb that commits dont introduce whitespace only changes :)

@vinothchandar Addressed comments.

Few cases to consider, for outstanding/pending tasks in the resubmitted stage

**Case A : Pending task succeeds `before` the stage resubmit is scheduled** 

 new duplicate tasks are not scheduled.  :) 

**Case B : Pending task fails `before`  or  `after` the stage resubmit is scheduled, its suppressed**

`before` must be from cascading fetch failures, as Spark expects. 
`after` is the case where the  new `CreateHandle` will delete the file being written & kill any pending task for same partition or more cascading fetch failures.. Honestly, rare that an executor goes down with fetch failure and other tasks still succeed! 

**Case C : succeeds `after` the stage gets resubmitted, `before` CreateHandle  is created for that file**

Then the duplicate tasks are scheduled and if any of them fail, its can cause inconsistent timeline & filesystem image, with incomplete parquet files.

If a single partition is writing a lot of files or much bigger file, then it gives more time between the completion of pending task and the create handle being issued, which I assume could be true for bulk insert use cases.. upsert() tends to keep this size smaller or 100mb per default, which can happen really fast, resulting in more case B than case C

**Potential Fixes** 

**A) Reconcile based on commit metadata**
If this happens rarely enough, we could just compare commit metadata with filesystem just before committing, error out and rollback the batch.  

**B) Move newer file to old file, instead of deleting** 
As a part of cleaning up leftover files for the partition in `LazyInsertIterable`, we could implement 

 - a check for valid parquet file (reading of footer length will suffice)
 - keep track of all left over files for that partition & implement a scheme to move/rename the new file to old name (to be consistent with timeline metadata) 
There are lots of cases to be handled here.. multiple files per LazyInsertIterable, different fileids in each run, multiple stage retries..

Oh wow! Nice find. 200 ms is a long time and we are likely to hit this more often with big shuffles having transient failures. 

Fix A is probably simple way to approach this, we can have a threshold for concurrent commits and rollback. Although there is no guarantee that this will fix it for all cases. 

I guess to have exactly once we need retries to agree on a file name. I guess that is what option B does. Will be interesting to hashout the other cases you mentioned.

@vinothchandar I see that you have put in the changes in `HoodieInputFormat` to read from commitAndCompactions timeline. Does it make sense to just deploy a new jar to the Hive servers instead of removing the .compaction action ?
Yes, a full upgrade on query engines will fix this as well. Just calling out a potential migration issue.

@vinothchandar I took a look at `ExternalAppendOnlyMap` used in Spark for spill use cases. As the name suggests, this implementation is AppendOnly, which means a key's value can be altered but it cannot be deleted, this makes handling deletes difficult. If we were to write our own implementation of a spillable map to support deletes, we'd run into the same issue as is the problem with this implementation (deleting data on disk which was spilled). 

To be able to use a spill based model for `CompactedLogScanner`, I'm suggesting the following changes

1. Remove concept of HoodieDeleteBlock. Essentially, for a deleted record entry, just write a HoodieRecord with an empty data value as part of the record. 
2. The `CompactedLogScanner` still merges the values for a particular key, which if deleted, will end up with a final merged view as a HoodieRecord with a empty data value.

How to delete records ?
1. On Disk, i.e, Compaction -> This is already handled in `HoodieMergeHandle` in COW, if there is a HoodieRecord with an empty data we skip writing it out to new compacted parquet file.
See here : https://github.com/uber/hoodie/blob/master/hoodie-client/src/main/java/com/uber/hoodie/io/HoodieMergeHandle.java#L136

2. In Memory, i.e, RTView -> `HoodieRealTimeInputFormat` and in turn `HoodieRealtimeRecordReader` at the moment just replaces data from old parquet with data from log files (returned from `CompactedLogScanner`). This means if the data is already written in the parquet file, removing from log files actually does not mean complete deletion. So this is actually NOT working as expected. See here : https://github.com/uber/hoodie/blob/master/hoodie-hadoop-mr/src/main/java/com/uber/hoodie/hadoop/realtime/HoodieRealtimeRecordReader.java#L297

Instead, what I'm proposing is as follows : 
a. `CompactedLogScanner` returns all records, even records which are meant to be deleted, with the data value as empty. So, no `HoodieDeleteBlock` required.
b. `HoodieRealtimeRecordReader` now iterates over the scanner records, if we find data value as empty, we update deltaRecordMap with the latest value. Now, when calling the next(..) method in `HoodieRealtimeRecordReader` we check if the value of record in `deltaRecordMap` is empty, if yes, then invoke the next(..) command again until a non-deleted record is found or the whole parquet file is read, whichever happens first. 

Please let me know your thoughts.

>  this implementation is AppendOnly, which means a key's value can be altered 
I have not dug much into it myself. But, does `AppendOnly` mean you can only add new k-v pairs?
 Not even update? 

If it does supports update, could we not implement deletes as soft deletes i.e change value to null, at the map level, instead of changing the upper layers like you mentioned. 

P.S: Let me think about the actual proposed changes more deeply in the meantime and get back
We already support soft deletes as upserts from the source (ingestion job). This is more for hard deletes.
@vinothchandar please take a pass when you get a chance

No what I meant is for "we'd run into the same issue as is the problem with this implementation (deleting data on disk which was spilled)." 

Why can't we update the map with a null instead of deleting on disk.
Well, the problem is during merge of this map (from RecordScanner) with the base parquet file. We cannot return null, we need to skip this row.
Closing for now.. We can reopen a new one and use this for reference going forward

### b) Fixes to deletes on MOR

@vinothchandar

Btw right now even figuring out partitions is hard-coded : https://github.com/uber/hoodie/blob/master/hoodie-hadoop-mr/src/main/java/com/uber/hoodie/hadoop/HoodieInputFormat.java#L289.
We will need to fix these before we can support generic partitioning logic.

Let me know what you think about introducing more configs to make the partition sorting more generic or keeping it hardcoded right now.

>Btw right now even figuring out partitions is hard-coded : 
Not true.. if partition metadata is found, it will pick the base path on-the-fly.. 

yeah still could n't follow how the `Comparator` would be used, since we only call the default constructor.. I suggest renaming the class to `DayBasedCompactionStrategy` and move on for now. date based partitioning is a big use-case anyway..

@vinothchandar So`getCommitTimeline and getCompletedCommitTimeline` returns the completed timeline for each table type, `commit` action for COW and `commit and deltacommit` for MOR.
We need another naming to handle returning only `commit` for MOR since many test cases need only `compacted` timeline. That's why I left the `compacted` naming there. Another way could be to re-factor all test cases to getCompletedCommitTimeline.filter("commit") to get the `compacted` timeline only but that seems repetitive and should be in one place. Thoughts ?
let me think about the timeline helpers more and propose something more holsitic.. your points are fair.
